answer_html: \(\displaystyle{}0=9i_3+7(i_3-i_1)+v_2\) as the linear equation for loop 3.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle{}0=9i_3+7(i_3-i_1)+v_2$ as the linear equation for loop 3.
hints_html: A resistor can only have 1 current going through it so any branches that share loop currents must be added together (with direction considered of course!)
hints_latex:
A resistor can only have 1 current going through it so any branches that
share loop currents must be added together (with direction considered of
course!)
hints_raw: A resistor can only have 1 current going through it so any branches that share loop currents must be added together (with direction considered of course!)
question: A 10
sols_html:
To be consistent with the labs, we will denote everything in terms of voltage drops so positive numbers are voltage drops and negative numbers are voltage gains.

In the third loop we move clockwise and start with the 9\(\Omega\) resistor. The voltage across this resistor (and any resistor) is given by Ohm’s Law V=IR so \(V_{9\Omega}=9i_3\) where we have a positive sign because we’re moving with the current and so there is a voltage drop. Next we come to the 7\(\Omega\) resistor which has both loop current 3 and loop current 1 flowing through it. Therefore there is a voltage drop contribution from loop current 3 by virtue that we’re moving in the direction of that current but there is also a voltage gain from loop current 1 going in the opposite direction. Therefore we get that \(V_{7\Omega}=7(i_3-i_1)\). Finally we reach the current source; since we are traversing it against the arrow we have a voltage drop and the value is one of our unknowns, \(v_2\). The Kirchhoff rule states that the sum of voltage drops and gains in a loop must be zero and so we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}0=9i_3+7(i_3-i_1)+v_2\end{aligned}\]

as the linear equation for loop 3.
sols_latex:
To be consistent with the labs, we will denote everything in terms of
voltage drops so positive numbers are voltage drops and negative numbers
are voltage gains.

In the third loop we move clockwise and start with the 9$\Omega$
resistor. The voltage across this resistor (and any resistor) is given
by Ohm's Law V=IR so $V_{9\Omega}=9i_3$ where we have a positive sign
because we're moving with the current and so there is a voltage drop.
Next we come to the 7$\Omega$ resistor which has both loop current 3 and
loop current 1 flowing through it. Therefore there is a voltage drop
contribution from loop current 3 by virtue that we're moving in the
direction of that current but there is also a voltage gain from loop
current 1 going in the opposite direction. Therefore we get that
$V_{7\Omega}=7(i_3-i_1)$. Finally we reach the current source; since we
are traversing it against the arrow we have a voltage drop and the value
is one of our unknowns, $v_2$. The Kirchhoff rule states that the sum of
voltage drops and gains in a loop must be zero and so we have that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}0=9i_3+7(i_3-i_1)+v_2
\end{align*}

as the linear equation for loop 3.
sols_raw:
To be consistent with the labs, we will denote everything in terms of voltage drops so positive numbers are voltage drops and negative numbers are voltage gains.

In the third loop we move clockwise and start with the 9<math>\Omega</math> resistor.  The voltage across this resistor (and any resistor) is given by Ohm's Law V=IR so <math>V_{9\Omega}=9i_3</math> where we have a positive sign because we're moving with the current and so there is a voltage drop.  Next we come to the 7<math>\Omega</math> resistor which has both loop current 3 and loop current 1 flowing through it.  Therefore there is a voltage drop contribution from loop current 3 by virtue that we're moving in the direction of that current but there is also a voltage gain from loop current 1 going in the opposite direction.  Therefore we get that <math>V_{7\Omega}=7(i_3-i_1)</math>.  Finally we reach the current source; since we are traversing it against the arrow we have a voltage drop and the value is one of our unknowns, <math>v_2</math>.  The Kirchhoff rule states that the sum of voltage drops and gains in a loop must be zero and so we have that

:<math>
\displaystyle{}0=9i_3+7(i_3-i_1)+v_2
</math>

as the linear equation for loop 3.
statement_html: In term of these unknowns [found in A9], write the linear equation that represents Kirchhoff’s law of voltage drops around the third loop (corresponding to \(i_3\)) in the circuit above.
